title: caledonia earthquake tsunami waves spotted
story: Authorities in the French territory have urged people to move more than  metresaway from the shore and,possible, to sites higher than  metresabove sea level after the .-magnitude quake.Initial reports suggested waves could reach up to three metreshigh.New Caledonia and Vanuatu ordered coastal evacuations today after a powerful undersea earthquake triggered tsunami warnings in the South Pacic, but appeared to have suffered little impact.The good news is, we have had no injuries or damage, said Oliver Ciry, a spokesman for New Caledonias directorate for civil protection and risk management.He added that abnormal movements of the sea off New Caledonias east coast and around the Loyalty Islands had been spotted earlier.Neighbouring Vanuatu also issued an evacuation warning.In a statement, the Pacic Tsunami Warning Centre said: Hazardous tsunami waves from this earthquake are possible within ,kmof the epicentre along the coasts of Vanuatu and New Caledonia.They said tsunami waves had been observed in the region, but did not say where.The undersea quake struck off the east coast of the island.The island shook as the tremor hit  miles  off the east coast of Australia.Its epicentre was shallow, at only six miles deep, causing the surface to rumble and shake.The quake hit  milessoutheast of the Loyalty Islands off New Caledonias east coast.New Caledonias high commission issued a tsunami warning for the island, ordering an immediate evacuation.The Directorate for Civil Protection and Risk Management of New Caledoniawarned: If you don’t have time to prepare your evacuation, get more than m away from the coast and or get to a height of more than m.However, the government said it was not expecting a destructive tsunami.In New Caledonia, the huge quake set off emergency warning systems, with residents receiving text messages advising them to move immediately to shelters on the island.Basile Citre, a county hall official on the Loyalty Island of Mare, told AFP: When the sirens sounded, the population headed for higher ground for safety.For now, nothing serious has happened.He told the agency he and fellow officials had been attending a meeting in the town hall when a tremor was noticed, ahead of the bigger shock.There have been multiple aftershocks of up to .-magnitude in the wake of the quake.New Zealand Civil Defence has confirmed that there is no tsunami threat to New Zealand following the .-magnitude earthquake.Geoscience Australia seismologists said a tide gauge on Mare Island, the second-largest of the Loyalty Islands, had registered a signal for a cm wave height.Seismologist Spiro Spiliopoulos told AFP: Based on that, we can say that this earthquake has generated a tsunami, but we don’t know the impact and how far it could go onshore.In a further update, though, the Pacic Tsunami Warning Center said: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of . occurred southeast of the Loyalty Islands at  on Wednesday.Based on all available data the tsunami threat from this earthquake has now passed.However, it has recommended government agencies responsible for any impacted coastal areas should monitor conditions at the coast to determineand when it is safe to resume normal activities.The organisation said that those located near impacted coastal areas should stay alert for information and follow instructions from local authorities.Dan McGarry, media director at Vanuatu Daily Post, tweeted that someone from Pango, just outside Port Vila, said: We ran a little as [the wave] rose rapidly. Beyond the reef was like a washing machine.McGarry added that there were three small surges reported from the southern island of Aneityum.He told ABC News in Australia: We get a lot of earthquakes every year. The tsunami warning was what was dferent this time, though.The broadcaster said local residents on Aneityum reported waves coming about  metres up the beach, and damaging some gardens.On the island of Aniwa, Issac Taseru told the ABC that a few homes had been damaged but there were no injuries reported.Minor sea level fluctuations of up to . metres above and below the normal tide may continue over the next few hours.New Caledonia was last stricken by a series of  magnitude tremors in August.It added to fears that a megaquake could strike after  earthquakes hit the planet in a week.New Caledonia is part of the notorious Ring of Fire, famed for being a hotbed of earthquake activity.Around  quakes are thought to have hit the Ring of Fire - a horseshoe-shaped area of volcanic belts, arcs and tectonic plates.The area stretches , miles from South America to Australia via the western United States and East Asia.It spreads across , milesfrom the southern tip of South America all the way to New Zealand, and includes Japan, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands.A whopping  per cent of the world’s earthquakes and  per cent of the world’s active and dormant volcanoes are contained within it.The Ring of Fire refers to a string of volcanoes, earthquake sites and tectonic plates around the Pacic.In January this year, tens of thousands of people had their lives disrupted because of a series of seismic and volcanic activity along it.There was an earthquake off Alaska, an avalanche and volcanic eruption in central Japan, and lava spewed from a volcano in the Philippines - all within days of each other.However, there was horric loss of le on Boxing Day, , when a .-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northern Sumatra, Indonesia.The tsunami generated by the quake was recorded nearly worldwide, and killed more than , people across  countries.The earthquake lasted up to  minutes, and caused the Earth to vibrate up to one centimetre.In September , Christchurch in New Zealand’s South Island was struck by a powerful .-magnitude earthquake which caused widespread destruction, smashing buildings and tearing up roads.As far as predicting when the next monster quake will hit, Prof Chris Elders, a geology expert from Curtin University in Australia, told the BBC this year that volcanic and tectonic activity has taken place in the region for hundreds and thousands of years.What you can say with confidence is that there will always continue to be earthquake and volcanic activity across dferent parts of the Ring of Fire.And a New Zealand volcanologist, Dr Janine Krippner, said while people worry that volcanic eruptions are becoming more frequent, the rate has not recently increased.Its just that we are more aware of activity as we now have satellites to capture more eruptions, and the internet to talk about more eruptions, she said.

title: nurseries stifling children
story: Ofsted’s annual report found kids’ muscular strength and dexterity is being suppressed because they’re not being allowed to clamber up climbing frames and hang from monkey bars.Boss Amanda Spielman said some nurseries had called a halt to outside school trips which could involve public transport or crossing roads as well as activities like climbing and even cooking because of possible “risks”.Experts said as well as holding back children’s physical development it also represses their appetite for adventure.She revealed yesterday many of her inspectors reported hearing from “unduly” risk-averse nurseries and called for a common sense approach – especially from parents.She said: “There’s a great deal of concern about children hurting themselves, concern about children having the lumps and bumps that are part of childhood.“It is very important that children can develop physically, explore, do all the things they need to do to test their physical boundaries.”She warned it was part of a child’s development to hurt themselves and to build strength and dexterity for writing when at school.Her report said: “We know that in the early years, a crucial part of preparing children for school is developing their muscular strength and dexterity.“The best nurseries recognise this and encourage children to be busy and active.“But we also know that in other settings this good practice is stled by undue concerns about the risk and safety of such activities.“While it is a basic expectation of any institution that cares for children to carry out proper risk assessments, some level of risk is an essential part of childhood.”Ofsted’s annual report found it was often parents’ concerns over risk putting private nurseries under pressure.Gill Jones, Ofsted’s expert in primary and early years, added: “Some private providers say that they have to work very hard with parents because parents want their children to be really safe when they leave their baby and their toddler in a setting.“They might not take children out on visits because of road safety. It is a fear thing. Anything with an element of danger.”Inspectors also called for greater powers to crackdown on illegal schools and found almost  schools were “stuck” in a cycle of poor performance.A Department for Education spokesperson said: “This report shows that standards in our schools are rising.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: odeon flogging 40 quid film tickets

title: hermes delivery driver toss christmas packages derbyshire
story: Chrissa Wadlow, , couldnt believe her eyes when she saw her deliveries chucked into the driveway of her Derbyshire home.The mum-of-four said: When I saw it, I was just shocked. title: north korea pink lady retire kim jong un
story: Ri Chun-hee is the most recognisable face of North Korean state television, and has been dubbed “The Pink Lady” for her famous bright pink Hanbok dress.The -year-old has appeared on the KCTV channel for decades and has announced some of the North’s most prominent propaganda.She is most famous for announcing the deaths of leaders Kim Il-sung in  and Kim Jong-il in , both times bursting into floods of tears.Ri is also renowned worldwide for her scathing criticisms of the West during her national broadcasts.But it has now been revealed that North Korean leader Kim Jong-un wants to modernise the country’s media, meaning Ri has been given less and less air-time over the past months.Under Kim’s direction, Ri has slowly been phased out in favour of younger, more glamorous presenters.And she could soon disappear from North Korean TV sets completely.Ri Chun-hee began working for North Korean TV in  and was appointed chief news presenter in the s.Nicknamed the pink lady, she usually wears a pink Western-style suit or traditional Hanbok dress.She has been characterised by her animated announcing style, resonant voice and sometimes vitriolic tone, having once been described as vaguely menacing.Her increasing absence from TV screens has been brushed off by North Korean officials as “semi-retirement”.The introduction of new faces to replace the veteran North Korean newsreader is not the only change Kim has brought to his country’s media services.In September, the North showcased their new high-tech studios, complete with a digital control room and autocue.Television broadcasts are now also littered with computer graphics that run in the background, and every effort is made to make pre-recorded news bulletins appear to be live.The changes are down to North Korean viewers becoming increasingly exposed to information from the outside world, including programming from South Korea.

title: universal credit advertising spend
story: An advertising blitz on social media, digital displays and posters at bus stops has been ramped up in the last few years, as critics hit out at the amount spent.FOIs sent to HuffPostUK shows the DWP had dished out a total of £,, on the campaign in the past three years.Around half a million was spent pumping ads out for the flagship scheme in , before spending more than tripled to £,, the following year.In  the total has so far reached more than £million.Separate FOIs from The Sun have shown the most cash in the last year was spent on billboard ads and at bus stops.Ministers also spent hundreds of thousands putting out out ads in local papers, on the radio, and used Facebook and Google as part of their Opening Up Work campaign.The campaign posters show people at work, and one caption reads: With Universal Credit you get a work coach to help you all the way.Philip Connolly, policy manager of Disability Rights UK told HuffPo the money was a waste. He said: “The best thing the government could have done is to spend the money telling people on previous benefits about this new benefit and write to them,” he said.The DWP provides services and benefits to around million people in the UK.Just over one million are now on the new flagship welfare system, Universal Credit, which rolls six benefits into one monthly payment.Only people who have a chance in circumstances or are making a new claim for help are put on the new system.But in the coming months and years everyone on the six benefits will be put on to it.So far the rollout has been beset with issues, with many Brits saying the five-week wait for help is getting them into debt.A Department of Work and Pensions spokesperson said: “We have a responsibility to advertise key policies and make people aware of available support. title: lockerbie 30 years on
story: The fully-laden passenger jet was blown up by a terrorists bomb in the skies over Scotland on December ,  - killing all  people on board.And ,ft below,  Lockerbie locals lost their lives when debris from the Boeing  crashed into residential ares, destroying  homes.Now amazing photographs show how the terror-struck town has been restored in the three decades since Libyan intelligence officer Abdelbaset al-Megrahi carried out the terror attack.On the fateful night, residents on the ground heard a low rumbling noise like thunder which rapidly increased to deafening proportions like the roar of a jet engine under power.And the accident report said: The noise appeared to come from a meteor-like object which was trailing flame and came down in the north-eastern part of the town.The Boeing  was heading for New York when it blew up about half an hour after taking off from Heathrow.Sections of the falling debris scattered out over a wide area - with the fuel-laden wing section falling on the Sherwood area of Lockerbie, where the  ground victims were killed in a massive jet-fuel explosion.Over , cops and  military personnel were rushed to the site of the disaster, but nearly all of the victims were killed.On December , investigators announced they had discovered traces of high explosives in the wreckage, confirming that the incident was an attack rather than an accident.In , Libyan intelligence officer Abdelbaset al-Megrahi was found guilty of the atrocity and sentenced to  years imprisionment.But he was released in  on compassionate grounds after being diagnosed with prostate cancer - from which he died in  at the age of .Earlier in , a review of his conviction was announced amid speculation that others were involved in the attack.A larger, dark, delta shaped object, resembling an aircraft wing, landed about the same time in the Sherwood area of the town.It was the fuel-filled wing that caused a very large fireball when it smashed into the earth in Sherwood, where all of the victims on the ground were killed.A huge crater was left where by the explosion - which was so powerful it measured . Richter Scale.Air crash investigators were able to recover around  per cent of the wreckage, which is now stored behind a high fence in a Lincolnshire scrapyard.Investigators were also able to determine that a small radio cassette player packed with plastic explosives in the planes hold was responsible for the explosion.It was the trace of explosives that confirmed the plane, travelling from Frankfurt to Detroit via New York and London, was not brought down by accident.Abdelbaset al-Megrahi was jailed for le for  counts of murder in connection with the bombing in .But he was released on compassionate leave in  when he was diagnosed with terminal prostate cancer - which killed him in  at the age of .

title: self service checkout internet mobile banking brits
story: Modern technology is saving Brits the equivalent of two weeks every year – or almost two-and-a-half years of the average adult letime, a study has found.A poll of , adults found the likes of self-service checkouts, internet shopping or banking and mobile traffic updates are saving Brits around six-and-a-half hours a week.Mobile devices alone are saving users around an hour per week in getting around, by helping us navigate more efficiently, giving traffic updates, and allowing us to check bus and train times.And time spent in the bank has decreased by  minutes per week in the last decade, as mobile and online banking has taken off.Email and social media are also among the top modern time-saving conveniences.Mathematician Katie Steckles, working in conjunction with Deichmann Shoes, calculated the amount of time technology is saving the nation, by analysing how long is spent in today’s world on everyday processes such as shopping, banking and checking-in for a flight.She revealed that with the average adult saving around six-and-a-half hours a week, this means the UK population as a whole could be saving a staggering  million hours a week or nearly  billion hours a year.Simon Wilson, head of buying at Deichmann, added: “Le has become busier than ever and we are constantly trying to find ways to save time.“We love nothing more than a time-saving hack with people using social media and the internet to find the best ways to boost the spare time they have.. Email. Microwaves. Online clothes shopping. A mobile phone. Online grocery food shopping. TV remote controls. Laptops. Mobile banking. Self-service checkouts. Ready meals. Sat-navs. Contactless payments. Online check-in for airports. Pay-at-pump petrol stations. Electric power tools. Apps. Streaming movies. Online bus train checkers. Portable batteries for recharging“Unfortunately, we all have le admin and tasks which while we might not want to do them, they need to be done, so making sure we do them in the most efficient way is important.The study found the average adult estimates internet banking saves them around  minutes a week, while online food shopping frees up another  minutes.Ready meals also save around  minutes a week and sat navs give people an extra  minutes a week by allowing them to avoid traffic jams.Self-service checkouts, online bus and train timetables and contactless payments also save more than  minutes a week each.The study also found  per cent of adults believe they have more time in recent years thanks to modern conveniences.Watching TV is the most popular way to spend any free time followed by reading books, listening to music and walking.* Deichmann shoes, which, in addition to an online shop, has  stores nationwide, all benefiting from an easy to navigate layout, where all styles and sizes are on display for people to help themselves to a shopping experience that’s more time efficient than normal shoe shops on average.Simon Wilson added: “Deichmann’s price guarantee, where we match or refund the dferencecustomers find an identical pair branded trainers cheaper in any UK high street or online retailer also saves time, as you don’t have to worry about shopping around before you buy.

title: kate middleton saluting airman cheeky smile
story: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have flown to an RAF base in the Mediterranean to honour military personnel serving overseas fighting ISIS this Christmas.And as Kate descended the steps from the plane, a saluting airman cheekily smiled at her from the bottom of the stairs.But the princess didnt seem to mind the grin and gave him a warm look in .Even husband William seemed to welcome the funny gesture as he too was pictured cracking up as he stepped on to the tarmac.William and Kate will use their trip to meet men and women separated from their loved ones over the festive period as they take part in active operations.On Tuesday the Cambridges staged a Christmas party for families from RAF Coningsby and RAF Marham who have a relative deployed abroad - including Cyprus.During the event, Kate told the invited wives, partners, grandparents and children: Not only are we grateful for you coming here to join our party, but also for the sacrices you make on a daily basis on behalf of the nation.During their brief visit to RAF Akrotiri on the Mediterranean island, the duke and duchess will meet military personnel, families living on the base, wider station personnel and members of the local community.The couple will visit and officially open the recently renovated Oasis centre, a recreation area used when the military are not on sht.They will also be bringing presents from some of the families they met on Tuesday for military personnel deployed at the RAF base.William is Honorary Air Commandant of RAF Coningsby in Lincolnshire, which is home to Typhoon squadrons which deploy to Cyprus and fly operations in support of Op Shader, the UKs contribution to the ongoing campaign against ISIS.They work alongside  Squadron, a Tornado GR unit based at RAF Marham in Norfolk, which is also involved with the campaign.RAF Akrotiri is the home of the Cyprus Operations Support Unit, which provides joint support to British Forces Cyprus and operations in the region to protect the UKs strategic interests.

title: theresa may humilated brexit cabinet revolt
story: A total of  Tory MPs allied with Labour, the SNP and Lib Dems to force the Government to take orders from the House of Commonsthe PM’s deal is voted down in six days time, as ministers expect.Tabled by former Attorney General Dominic Grieve, the rebel amendment was passed by  v , a majority of .It left shell-shocked Mrs May facing an all-or-nothing mighty showdown on Tuesday next week.In a further hammer blow for the PM that left her authority hanging by a thread, the rebels also included an array of senior loyalists – such as ex-Cabinet ministers Damian Green, Sir Michael Fallon and Sir Oliver Letwin, as well as grandees Sir Nicholas Soames, Richard Benyon, Nick Boles and Ed Vaizey.The centrist Tories insisted they were helping No block a No Deal outcome, which they say will devastate the economy.Mrs May’s ex-de facto deputy until last year Mr Green told The Sun: “I wanted to leave options open for the Government and others to prevent No Deal, which would be disastrous”.Former Fisheries minister Mr Benyon added: “I support the PMs deal butit fails I want Parliament to have the option to prevent UK crashing out”.But handing decision making powers to Parliament also means a simple majority of MPs could vote toStruggling to react to the blow, No refused to confirm whether Mr Grieve’s amendment would hand Parliament control of what happens next.The PM’s official spokesman would only say that any MPs’ instruction would simply “reflect the will of the House”.Senior Brexiteers called on No to stare down any majority of MPs that try to push Mrs May around.Former Tory leader Iain Duncan-Smith insisted: “The Clerk of the Commons was clear that any such vote does not bind the Government.“It will be a meaningless vote. The British people voted to leave and Parliament cannot frustrate that.”But privately, senior No admitted that while any Commons motion would not be legally binding, it would be politically impossible to ignore the will of the House of Commons.As Westminster was plunged into a frenzy after the shock vote, some loyal Tory MPs claimed the hammer blow could actually help Mrs May win round wavering colleagues to get the letters in.Look what a disaster Theresa May is making of Brexit”.The drama came just minutes before Theresa May fired the starting gun on the biggest show down in Parliament in decades.A few minutes after the crippling defeat, the PM was forced to take to the Despatch Box to open the marathon five day debate on her deal.After arguing for eight hours each day, MPs then vote on the  page Withdrawal Agreement and  page Political Declaration for a future trade deal at pm next Tuesday night.Imploring the Commons to back her deal and save her Government, the PM surprised MPs by swtly signalling she could make a fresh concession to Eurosceptics on the hated Irish backstop.Separately Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn incensed Brexiteers by saying that reopening the negotiations couldn’t be ruled out.And in incredible scenes, Tory MPs turned on each other as Boris Johnson labelled the PM’s deal a “national humiliation” and said it was “finely balanced” whether Britain would be better off staying in the EU.In a passionate hour long address, the PM said she was aware of the fierce opposition to the so-called Irish ‘backstop’.And she said: “I have listened to those concerns.I want us to consider how we could go further.“And I will be meeting colleagues to find an acceptable solution.”Government sources indicated this could involve giving MPs a vote on approving the activation of the insurance plan in .The PM had earlier warned that reopening the Withdrawal Agreement was impossible – and would give EU member states the chance to wrestle back wins from the UK in areas such as fisheries.In a charged debate, Labour’s Yvette Cooper accused the PM of not being “straight” with the House on the failure to agree a comparable deal on security co-operation.And DUP leader Nigel Dodds hit back at claims his party didn’t represent the pro-Remain feeling in Northern Ireland by saying he wasn’t afraid of another General Election.Original Maastricht rebel Christopher Gill could be seen shouting “outrageous, outrageous” from the peers gallery as the PM spoke.But in a passionate address, the PM urged the House to back her deal, reunite the country and put Britain on course for a brighter future.She said: “This argument has gone on long enough corrosive to our politics and le depends on compromise.”Defending the way she has handled the negotiations, the PM insisted that while she could have “banged on the table” and “faced criticism from all sides”, she had done what she believed was best for Britain.She said: “I didn’t play to the gallery. I focused on getting a deal that honours the referendum, sets us on course for a bright future, and I did so through painstaking hard.“Because I have never thought politics was simply about broadcasting your own opinions on the matter at hand.”Defending her record, she added: “When the EU gave us a choice between off the shelf models, I won a bespoke deal.“When in Salzburg the EU tried to insist on a backstop that carved out Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK I faced them down and they backed down.And right at the end when Spain tried to make a move on Gibraltar I stood firm and protected Gibraltar’s sovereignty.”She said: “Don’t let anyone think there is a better deal to be won by shouting louder.Don’t imagine thatwe vote this down a dferent deal is going to miraculously appear. The alternative is uncertainty and risk.“I don’t say this deal is perfect it was never going to be, that’s the nature of a negotiation.Yes it is a compromise it speaks to the hopes and desires of our fellow citizens who voted to leave and those who voted to stay in.“We will not bring our country togetherwe seek a relationship that gives everything to one side of the argument and nothing to the other.“We should not let the search for the perfect Brexit prevent a good Brexit.”But in a staggering sign of civil war in the Tory party, Conservative MPs turned on Boris Johnson as the former Foreign Secretary said no MP would “sincerely believe” is a good one.In a barb at Brexit-backing members in the Cabinet he added that it appears “those sent out to support it know it is a democratic disaster”.He also called for the Government to withhold the £ billion orce bill until the EU has agreed a trade deal. He stormed: “In Brussels they think they have us beat and our nerve will fail.“They think we have got nothing left in our tank and that we want to do a deal at any price.“Now is the time as we all think about this vote for us to show that they grossly underestimate this country.But in a series of Tory counter-attacks ex-Minister Ed Vaizey stood up to insist he “sincerely” believed in Theresa May’s deal.And fellow Brexiteer Roger Gale intervened to pan him for preferring “grievance to the solution”.Backbenchers then howled with laughter when the big hitter said we may be - down against the EU but “we can win -”.The PM walked out  minutes into her arch enemy’s address.With the PM listening on Boris ripped apart her deal and joked that it had achieved an “extraordinary thing” in bringing Remainers together with Leavers and “uniting the whole Johnson family”.“This is a national humiliation that makes a mockery of Brexit.”To heckling he summed up by warning people who voted Leave in  voted for change, not an “endless transition or thinly disguised version of the status quo”.He stormed: “It is a paint and plaster pseudo Brexit and beneath the camouflage we find the same old EU institutions the customs union  single market.“The people of this country voted for freedom, they voted for independence and for a better Britain and for a country where politicians actually listen to what they have to say andwe try to cheat them now they will not forgive us.”Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had earlier accused Mrs May of putting the country over a barrel.To the packed Chamber – which had earlier included Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson and her baby - he said: “Following the  election, the Prime Minister could have attempted to build a consensus, recognising the new arithmetic of Parliament, and sought a deal that brought people together.“Instead, just like her predecessor - who called a referendum without preparing for the eventuality of a Leave vote - the Prime Minister has seen these negotiations only as an exercise in the internal management of the Conservative Party.”He added: “This Government is not taking back control, it is losing control.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc boss kamal ahmed labels brexit a bit rubbish
story: Kamal Ahmed wrote to fellow BBC correspondents about the future of Britain on how the broadcasters should present Brexit.The email, published by Guido Fawkes, went on to say that journalists should get across to audiences that after Brexit the economy is “likely to be worse off”.He added to the email: “The point to get across to audiences is the broad one – under any Brexit scenario the economy is likely to be worse off.“On the Brexit economic forecasts,we leave the impression ‘well it might be right, it might be wrong’ we would be doing a disservice to our audiences.“On economicsthe evidence from expert modellers who know what they are talking aboutis clear – it’s a bit rubbish.”Ahmed previously worked as the economics editor until earlier this year when he got a promotion.A spokesman for the BBC said they had no comment on the email leak.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government constitutional stand off
story: Theresa May lost a crucial Commons vote by  to  over her refusal to publish the full legal advice on her EU deal.The “contempt” motion is not known to have been passed against a sitting Government in Parliament’s  years of existence.Despite an earlier express demand from the Commons, No  and Cabinet ministers insisted publication would be a fatal mistake.Accusing Labour of “playing parlour games”, they argued that it was “in the national interest” to keep Attorney General Geoffrey Cox’s verdict under wraps as the precedent could give away national secrets in the future.Mrs May also told the Cabinet that ministers would be in breach of the ministerial codethey did.But the minority government stood little chance of holding off the move after its DUP allies sided with Jeremy Corbyn.Conceding defeat moments after the vote, Commons leader Andrea Leadsom agreed to publish the “final and full” legal advice that Mr Cox gave to the Cabinet as they deliberated the EU deal.The move was seen as a desperate Government bid to escape Parliament’s punishment for the contempt ruling, which could include seeing Mr Cox suspended or even expelled from the Commons.In a second blow, Mrs May also lost a vote on passing on her bid to give the decision on what punishment to mete out to MPs’ Privileges Committee by  to .The move would bury the decision for weeks, but the Commons will now decide on Mr Cox’s fate in a vote this week.Labour’s Brexit spokesman Sir Keir Starmer said the contempt ruling was “a badge of shame” for the Government.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: secret legal advice on brexit published
story: Evenboth parties believe that the talks have completely broken down on a trade deal, then Britain will have to stay tied to the bloc to prevent a hard border in Ireland, todays bombshell dossier shows.The legal advice ministers tried to keep a secret from MPs has finally been published this morning, giving a damning verdict on the PMs deal with the EU.After a humiliating defeat in the Commons last night where ministers were found to be in contempt for the first time ever, they finally agreed to make it public.MPs voted to defy the Government and release the full documents - rather than just a summary.Buried in the small text it confirms that evenBritain is still negotiating with the EU years later and both parties think talks have broken down, then the UK still cant get out of the customs union backstop.It says: In international law the protocal would endure indefinitely until a superceding agreement took its place, in whole or in part.And it went on to say: The protocal is intended to subsist even when negotiations have clearly broken down.The legal advice also blasted Mrs Mays claims that a review of the situation could get us out of it.The small print read it does not provide for a mechanism that is likely to enable the UK lawfully to exit the UK wide customs union without a subsequent agreement.It said that because there was no right to end the backstop, there was a legal risk that the UK might become subject to protracted and repeating rounds of negotiations.And the legal advice also caused a fresh headache for Mrs Mays Northern Ireland allies, the DUP.The notes today said that goods travelling between Great Britain to Northern Ireland will be subject to a declaration process, it added, saying GB is essentially treated as a third country by NI for goods...Regulatory checks would have to take place at airports or ports - but the EU did say that many of these could take place away from the border.The DUPs Nigel Dodds, who has said his party and  MPs wont support the PM in Governmentthe deal passes, said: No wonder they tried to hide the legal advice. Devastating advice from AG.He said the text proved that Northern Ireland would be in full EU customs union while GB is not - putting in a barrier between Northern Ireland and the rest of the country.And Lib Dem Brexit spokesperson Tom Brake blasted: “Nobody voted for Britain to be trapped in a Brexit hamster wheel, constantly haggling with close partners on trade as the country gets poorer.Today Commons leader Andrea Leadsom said MPs will live to regret forcing the Government into publishing it.It was just one of three votes Theresa Mays administration lost last night.The news comes as:She said it undermined decadesnot centuries of convention where ministers were able to receive advice in secret.And she would only back Mrs May as PM at the moment.The Prime Minister will face PMQs in the Commons later today, followed by the continuation of the debate on her Brexit deal.MPs will have their crunch vote on it next week - where the PM is all but certain to lose.Ms Leadsom said today thatthe PMs deal was thrown out in the vote next week, Britain would leave without a deal.Other MPs are determined to stop that happening, saying theres no majority for that to pass in the Commons.Unless government were to do something completely dferent to change tack, or indeed to pass this deal, then we will be leaving the EU on  March next year without a deal, so it defaults to no deal, Ms Leadsom said this morning.Last night MPs won the power to block No Deal and call a second referendumthe PM lost the vote.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: foodbanks not just photo opportunity
story: NewsFoodbanks are not just a photo opportunity for Tory MPs says Jeremy CorbynIn a stinging attack the Labour leader accused the Government of creating a "hostile environment" for those on benefitsShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video pmqs-full-blow-blow-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn launched a devastating tear down of the governments welfare policies telling MPs that foodbanks are not just a photo opportunity for Conservative MPs. In a stinging attack the Labour leader accused the Tories of creating a hostile environment for those on benefits. He referred to a string of photographs of Tory MPs at foodbanks in their constituencies which have been promoted on social media in recent weeks.Mr Corbyn was visibly angered when the Prime Minister dismissed again the findings of the UN Special Rapporteur who said the Government’s policies and drastic cuts were “entrenching high levels of poverty and inflicting “unnecessary” hardship in one of the richest countries in the world. Asked which part of the report she found most shocking, Theresa May responded: We have been clear ashas been, that we dont agree with this report because what we actually see in our country today is absolute poverty at record lows, more people in work than ever before, youth unemployment almost halved, wages growing - and thats because of the balanced approach we take to our economy.  In his report Mr Alston, said the Government’s policies and drastic cuts were “entrenching high levels of poverty and inflicting “unnecessary” hardship in one of the richest countries in the world. His damning report said ministers were “in denial” about how the Universal Credit had pushed people into poverty. Today Mr Corbyn said the Government does not agree with his findings because the report presents an unpalatable truth. He added: The new Work and Pensions Secretary seems to have taken a lesson from her and created a hostile environment for those that are claiming benefits.  One of the Governments policies that is causing the greatest anxiety and poverty is Universal Credit, the UN rapporteur Professor Alston said it was fast falling into universal discredit. When will the Prime Minister demonstrate some of her professed concern about burning injustices and halt the roll-out of Universal Credit   Mrs May responded by saying the Government had listened to concerns about the benefit and had made changes. Fury erupted on the Tory benches after Mr Corbyn, during his final question, said: When I hear a Prime Minister talking about dficult decisions, what always happens afterwards in this context is the poorest lose out in our society - . million disabled people are now in poverty, , were hit by appalling cuts to the Employment Support Allowance benefit alone last year. This Government labelled disabled people scroungers, it called those unable to work skivers... Mrs May could be seen saying outrageous, while Tory colleagues shouted Withdraw! at Mr Corbyn, which prompted Commons Speaker John Bercow to intervene.  Mr Bercow took against Home Secretary Sajid Javid for offering advice, adding: He should seek to discharge his own obligations in his office to the best of his ability - I require no advice fromon the discharge of mine. Be clear about that. Mr Corbyn added: This Government also created a hostile environment for the Windrush generation. Mrs May faced MPs after bruising triple defeat in the House of Commons on Tuesday night. The SNPs Ian Blackford accused the Prime Minister of concealing the facts on her Brexit deal after her government became the first to be found in contempt of Parliament.  He said: We were promised strong and stable - what weve got is a Government in crisis. The MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber asked: Is it time that the Prime Minister took responsibility for concealing the facts on her Brexit deal from members in this House and the public  Will she take responsibility  Mrs May insisted the full legal advice the government was forced to publish was the same as the shortened statement made earlier this week.

title: hooray uk parliament doing job
story: NewsopinionHooray! The UK Parliament is doing its job properly for the first time in almost a decadeThis is how democracy is supposed to work, peopleShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen politicians are unsure, they ask the people to decide. When the people cant, they tell politicians to figure it out. The courts pick their way through the detail trying to be fair to all sides, and only the journalists try to explain why its complicated. So it is with capital punishment, terrorism, drone strikes, tax reforms, benefit cuts and everything  in le. Most of us expect complexity, relying on others to help us find a balance that doesnt kill us. We vote for representatives, then ask them to rely on their judgement to decide everything until we demand they rely on ours. But with Brexit the whole things gone cockeyed. We voted for those who suggested our relationship with the EU was simple. Parliament voted enthusiastically for a simple referendum. The people gave a simple answer, the government issued a simple letter. The courts were the first ones to decide it was complicated and journalists have spent the past two years failing to explain much at all. Its hardly surprising were now in a world where simple people still demand a simple Brexit and that politicians rely on the people to figure it out for them. A ComRes poll shows that people oppose remaining in the EU, oppose leaving with Theresa Mays deal, oppose a second referendum and oppose leaving without a deal. Their big idea instead is to renegotiate, despite the fact weve done that for two years and all the clowns achieved was a joke buttonhole that squirts water at the EU infor poundbillion. Politicians are now so confused about whos supposed to be doing what that the Disgraced Dr Liam Fox says theres a real danger that MPs may attempt to stealBrexit from the British people, and Michael Gove said that not delivering a simple thing that isnt possible because its more complicated than that would be a fatal blow to faith in democracy. Andrea Leadsom smilingly added that Parliamentarians who want to be in government in the future will live to regret the decision they took last night, as though she were a Mafia consigliere threatening painful retribution against those who disrespected the Prime Minister. Lets just stop there. Lets go back a bit, and explain. In  there was a massive, global, banking crash. Had it been ignored by politicians everyone would be living out of dustbins by now. All right, Richard Branson would be in Necker and Alan Sugar on his yacht, but it would be dustbins for them too.   Politicians worldwide did their jobs and figured out a solution. Two years later there was a general election and the people couldnt pick a team, so politicians had to form their own. Bizarrely, the party that came second wasnt part of it. The not-quite winners teamed up with the actual-losers and took power with barely a flicker of democratic concern.In the years that followed they housed immigrants in areas that rarely voted for their parties. Despite the fact such people produced more tax than they spent, they cut services in those places more than in friendlier ones. The aim, and result, was that Labour-voting areas became more xenophobic and more likely to turn Tory on immigration issues. They declared the previous administration profligate, then accumulated so many debts theyve started selling them off. They promised a northern powerhouse, while investing poundbn in the south and cutting investment by poundbn in the north.Thats not normal behaviour for politicians of any stripe, as theyre usually fully aware they can be sacked at short notice. But THIS lot established fixed, five-year contracts, which meant democracy was limited.When we were finally allowed a vote, the people picked the team which had been doing all the above but pretending that it wasnt. That team then opted to protect itself - not the country - by offering a referendum on leaving the EU which it thought no-one would want to do. But the people, now thoroughly confused by lies, theft, quantitative easing, Question Time, austerity, bananas and everything  hurled at them for years, picked the easy road - the f*** it road. The team captains ran away, the pound noseed, and those left on the field started barking the chaos was all Project Fear and could be completely ignored.   A new team captain activated Article  and told Parliament it had no say. The courts intervened to say Parliament was sovereign. Newspapers said judges were the enemy. Parliament was cowed into backing Article , even though it was vague and fully-revokable.The government then spent two years not negotiating a deal that isnt actually a deal, before telling the people and Parliament its the only option when it isnt. Few people notice that were preparing to leave the EU with , more people in poverty than we had  years ago, or have asked whether Brexit is in their interests.When the four estates of a democratic nation are in such turmoil and acting in direct opposition to their normal roles, there is nothing to do but hold on and hope for the best. And now, the ship of state is righting itself. Journalists are explaining complexities and detail. Judges are regarded as refuge. And Parliament has, finally, begun holding government to account.   For the first time in history, those ruling the country have been proven to be in contempt of our democratic processes. For the first time since the Brexit vote, the government has been forced to bow to the will of those figuring things out on behalf of the people. And for the first time in  years the Mother of Parliaments is acting like a grown-up - something that happens when loyal MPs rebel for a principle, when politicians seek to listen to one anothers arguments, when the people take an interest in what is being decided on their behalf. Nothing is perfect. We live in a world where racists claim the same freedom of expression as journalists, and believe that makes it all right to hurl homophobic slurs at a columnist while chasing him down the street, to threaten Jewish MPs online, to cause BBC reporters to need bodyguards. In the past decade, the confusion in our system has been fed by fake news, populism and idiots. The reason that these things - more properly called propaganda, fascism and the unelectable - do not dominate our world is because the system self-corrects. Each part pushes and pulls against the others, and the result is stable, slow, progress.  That is what happened in Parliament yesterday. Its what, hopefully, will continue this week while they vote on Brexit. Remember ityou are asked to vote again. Remember it when a journalist tries to explain, when judges rule, when MPs rebel and amend and argue. Elsewhere, with Parliaments that do not scrutinise the government, dictators hold power. Where journalists cannot explain, the people are kept in ignorance. And where those things are actively attacked, the world grows dark -  journalists were murdered this year while  languish in jail, most of them for crimes against the state. While Putin and Bin Salman high-five after the dismemberment of a journalist, remember that reporters are the first bit of democracy that dies. In their wake come the opponents, the judges, and then the people. However confusing and chaotic your democracy is, hold on to it. Be glad you have an MP, especiallythey dont always do as theyre told. Seek out a journalist whos explained well and say thank you, because the occasional pat is the only encouragement they need to keep headbutting walls. Note what happens when people dont vote, and make sure you do. Above all, be glad you have an opportunity to argue about your nations direction, and that youre not the only one steering the ship.

title: snp leader told suggesting theresa
story: NewsSNP leader told off for suggesting Theresa May misled MPs about her Brexit dealIan Blackford was ordered to withdraw his comments at PMQs, after saying the Prime Minister misled the house, perhaps inadvertentlyShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video ian-blackford-gets-told-accusing-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The SNPs Westminster leader has been told off for suggesting Theresa May misled MPs about her Brexit deal.Ian Blackford accused the Prime Minister of misleading the house inadvertently or otherwise, in a frosty exchange during Prime Ministers Questions.It came after ministers were forced to publish legal advice given to the Government by Attorney General Geoffrey Cox , which Mr Blackford suggested were at odds with the Prime Ministers statements.He said: We were promised strong and stable. What we have is a Government in crisis. A Government which has lost two Brexit Secretaries, a Home Secretary, a Foreign Secretary, a Work and Pensions Secretary. A Government which has suffered from three consecutive defeats in just two hours. The first government to do so in  years. And now a government found to be in contempt of Parliament. Is it time that the Prime Minister took responsibility, a responsibility for concealing the facts on her Brexit deal from members of this house and the public. Will she take responsibility   Mrs May denied concealing the facts on the deal, adding: “What he will see is that the legal position that was set out on Monday in the -page document together with the statement made, and the answers to questions given by the Attorney General on Monday, very clearly set out the legal position.” Mr Blackford responded: “That is an incredibly disappointing response from the Prime Minister. “The facts have had to be dragged out of this government by Parliament. “This morning we have seen the detail of the legal advice. We have seen the facts that the government tried to hide. “Mr Speaker, this government is giving Northern Ireland permanent membership of the Single Market and the Customs Union. “The legal advice is clear, it states: ‘Despite statements in the protocol that is not intended to be permanent, in international law would endure indefinitely.’ “Since the Prime Minister ed from Brussels with her deal, the Prime Minister has been misleading the house inadvertently or otherwise.”  MPs are not allowed to accuse other MPs of lying, or deliberately misleading the House. It’s considered ‘unparliamentary’. Speaker John Bercow interrupted Mr Blackford, ordering him to withdraw the words ‘or otherwise’. But the SNP’s Westminster leader failed to withdraw the accusation, merely adding: “I did use the word inadvertently, and I repeat it. “The Prime Minister ed from Brussels with her deal. The Prime Minister has been misleading the house, perhaps inadvertently.” Again, Speaker Bercow got involved, telling Mr Blackford: “There can be no imputation of dishonour. And the insertion of the word ‘perhaps’ suggests the right honourable gentleman wants to keep his options open. “The option of imputing dishonour does not exist. That word must now be removed.” He ordered him to “rephrase, continue and complete, briefly.”  Mr Blackford responded: “I say again, inadvertently,” going on to ask the PM why she “continues to deny Scotland the rights and opportunities her deal offers to other parts of the United Kingdom.” Mrs May again insisted a “careful analysis” of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox’s statements and answers in the House would reveal no dference with the legal advice the Government was forced to publish today. She added: “I have myself said on the floor of this house that there is indeed no unilateral right to pull out of the backstop. “What I have also said is that it’s not the intention of either party that the backstop shouldbe used in the first place, or should it is used, should be anything other than temporary.” The legal advice from Attorney General Geoffrey Cox to Theresa May admits the Northern Ireland backstop could endure indefinitely. And it confirms the government would not legally have the power to remove the UK from the fallback position, which would keep Britain in the customs union to avoid a hard border in Ireland, without agreement from the EU. It comes after MPs on Tuesday found the Government to be in contempt of Parliament for the first time in modern history.

title: theresa loses brexit vote what
story: NewsIf Theresa May loses the Brexit vote this is what could happen nextThe Prime Minister appears doomed to certain defeat, unable to cobble together the numbers to force her blueprint through the CommonsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politicsBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  DEC NewsTheresa May faces the fight of her political le "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf  MPs back Theresa May’s Brexit deal she will emerge victorious on Tuesday. The Tories have  MPs, plus she has a confidence and supply deal with Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party, so all will be well for the Prime Minister, yes  Emphatically, no. In fact, she appears doomed to certain defeat, unable to cobble together the numbers to force her blueprint through the Commons. Thanks to Mrs May needlessly squandering David Cameron’s hard-won,fragile, majority at last year’s snap general election - the one she never needed to call - she has to rely on the DUP to win parliamentary votes. But despite the poundbillion bung she conjured up for the Ulster hardliners, the DUP will not support the pact because elements of the deal would make Northern Ireland dferent from the rest of the UK. That strips away the PM’s stitched-together majority in a trice. In her own party, insiders believe up to nine Tory Remainers could vote against the deal, piling further pressure on the premier.   And then there is the European Research Group, a seemingly innocent name for the Conservatives’ hardline Brexiteers. Scores of its members are set to revolt unless Mrs May conjures a compromise. Sources estimate up to  Tory MPs could vote against the deal. While some Labour MPs may rebel against Jeremy Corbyn and offer their support, it is highly unlikely to be anywhere near enough to save the PM’s pact. What happened in the Commons yesterday  Theresa May lost three crucial votes. MPs backed a Labour amendment which held the Government in contempt for refusing to publish its full legal advice on the Brexit plan. The advice will now be released, and could confirm the worst fears of the Brexiteers – making even more of them likely to vote down the deal. Then MPs backed an amendment by Tory MP Dominic Grieve which would give MPs a say on what happensTheresa May’s Brexit deal is voted down. This means they could block a no-deal Brexit, send the Prime Minister back to the negotiating table or even call for a second referendum. The PM is no longer in control of Parliament or the Brexit process.   Can Brexit be halted  Remainers have seized on the provisional findings of the The European Court of Justice’s advocate general, who said the UK can decide on its own to cancel its withdrawal from the EU. It is not a binding judgment but suggests the ECJ will come to the same conclusion in its official ruling. This would allow us to revoke Article , the two-year mechanism Mrs May triggered which started the countdown to our departure on March , . What happens next  The key moment is on Tuesday when MPs vote on Mrs May’s Brexit plan. Unless she persuades Tory rebels to change their mind she is heading for almost certain defeat. More than  Conservative MPs, the DUP, the vast majority of Labour MPs,  Lib Dems and the SNP have all said they will vote down the proposal. But some Brexiteers may take fright at Mr Grieve’s amendment, fearing it could scupper Brexit. What does the Prime Minister doshe loses  We are in uncharted territory. The law says Mrs May has toto Parliament within  days with an updated response. Much will depend on the scale of defeat. If it is close she could try to wring further concessions from Brussels. If she is heavily defeated she will be under intense pressure to resign.   Where does that leave Brexit  Nobody knows. MPs could send the PM back to Brussels but that would need the EU to agree to extend Article . Or Mrs May could call a snap election. This is a high-risk move for the Tories as it could land Jeremy Corbyn in No . MPs could also decide only a second referendum can break the deadlock. The default is that we crash out without a deal. But most MPs will do everything they can to prevent what they see as an economic calamity.

title: educating manchester head drew povey
story: NewsEducating Manchester head Drew Povey says council bullied him in harrowing investigationDrew Povey from Educating Greater Manchester was suspended from Harrop Fold school with the local council heavily criticising how it was run - here, for the first time, he gives his version of eventsShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsDrew Povey at his home in Warrington "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHes the headteacher who became the star of Channel ’s series Educating Greater Manchester for transforming a high school branded one of the worst in the country. So when Drew Povey was suspended from Harrop Fold in July after being investigated for administrative errors, staff and pupils launched a campaign to have him reinstated. But Drew, , quit in September. Now an Ofsted report has placed the school, in Little Hulton, back in to special measures after it deemed the school inadequate in all five categories. The local council blames the schools problems on long standing issues and historic practices. Now for the first time Drew fully explains his emotional toll at seeing the school’s progress unravel and why he believes he was ousted from the job he loved. “It was a dim, dark and cold December lunchtime when I arrived at some green gates. I pressed a buzzer and waited a while till eventually a voice over the intercom asked, “Hello, can I help ”.   I said, “I’m Drew Povey and I’ve come for the Christmas concert.” Driving into the carpark I saw an old building that looked a bit like a factory, with the odd frosted window and bars outside. I eventually found the entrance, where a sign that had seen better days and with peeling paint read: “Welcome to our school”. Inside, a typical lunchtime in a busy second school was in full swing. The smell of chips, the hubbub of kids chatting, and some music playing in the background. As I walked to reception, I noticed two queues of students. One was very long and they were holding pink tickets. The other, only had a handful of kids holding green ones. It took me a moment, then I realised that this was the way the free school meals kids were separated from the payers. The kids in the pink queue were all on free school meals. I was given a tour of the school and that’s when I saw all needed to see. Kids making chip butties and chatting excitedly about the Christmas holidays. On the yard, kids were playing football and basketball, with others hanging around eating packed lunches and laughing. The students told me about their friends and the teachers they liked most. The staff looked tired,but were buzzing about the students who were doing great things and the couple that were harder to reach.   The bell rang for the end of lunch and the energy was like nothing I’d seen in a school before. I stood smiling and saying ‘hello’ and kids responded with ‘hiya’ and a look that said, ‘who are you ’ I went into the hall and the concert started. Four students at the piano, unorms perfect and chests puffed out with pride. At the point, I knew this was they place I wanted to be. They had me heart and soul from that point on. This was Harrop Fold in , the ‘worst school in the country’, but with a charm that literally took my breath away. I started at the school in charge of pastoral care – my perfect job. The next few years were challenging and tough,but the school soon came out of special measures. My goal was to work with the students to get them to own their school and to encourage staff to raise the bar even more. In , I was called into the Head’s office. I’d seen the Chair of Governors arrive and the Council’s Director of Children’s Services. This could either be very good news, or very bad. They asked meI’d be interested in being the Headteacher – the proudest moment of my career. I agreed on the condition that I would be able to do what I thought was best for the community. The following nine years were simply amazing. There are just too many high points to list, but thebest part was seeing the students start to believe in themselves and whole school’s confidence grow.   The once maligned blue blazer became respected and the community got behind us for the first time. People starting saying, ‘this is a good school’. In January  we started the new year with new hope, anticipation and optimism. The students and staff had just voted to do another series of Educating Greater Manchester, and our reputation was continuing to grow, and the school was now considerably over-subscribed. The Council had been in touch early in the term to say they had spotted an error in the census data that we submit to them. We looked into it, and it was clear that a mistake had been made, relating to how – students had been recorded. Queries were also raised about how the attendance of two students had been recorded, and about a student being sent home early after a conversation with parents. We met with officials from Salford City Council, accepted full responsibility and held our hands up to the mistakes and set out how we were now changing processes so that this didn’t happen again. Everyone thought that was the end of it. But it was just the beginning. In March the Council came back to us to say they needed to investigate further. And then in July three members of staff, myself included, were suspended. The implication was clear: they believed we were trying to massage our results by recording students as not being on roll .   What had clearly been an administrative error - which was corrected as soon as we were aware - had now been blown up into a set of accusations that were questioning our integrity and our honesty. But something didn’t stack up. Whilst the error should certainly not have been made, it only involved a tiny number of students. Did that really warrant suspensions and a costly investigation  And besides,we were in the business of massaging results and chasing grades, there are certainly be far more effective ways to do that at Harrop. If we had wanted to, we could have squeezed another –% from our results by having a dferent approach. We are a genuinely inclusive community school. This means we don’t exclude pupilsand we have signicant numbers of students who have additional needs not normally seen in mainstream schools. We also accept what are called “managed moves” – in other words, students who have struggled at other schools and move school to have a fresh start. Many schools just don’t have this same inclusive approach, andwe followed suit, our results would look a hell of lot more impressive than they do now. Which was why the implied accusation just beggared belief. I’m not one for conspiracy theories I’m a typical northern lad who loves what he does for a living, loves his family, and loves – for my sins – Everton. But to my mind, the approach that Salford Council took seemed to be utterly disproportionate. Something  was driving this and as the investigation dragged out over the summer, into September and now seemingly likely to stretch further into the autumn with still no resolution in sight, it has become increasingly clear that the end goal was to get me out. The reasons for this are actually pretty simple. It’s fair to say that I’ve been a thorn in Salford City Council’s side for some time. I’m no diplomat and I speak plainly.   When I arrived at Harrop, the single biggest challenge was nothing to do with the kids, or the teachers, or even the building. The school was utterly hamstrung by a debt of pound.m that had been racked up under the Council’s direction. Expensive but largely ineffective consultants were bought in during the time the school was struggling. They added very little to the school, other than an almighty bill. Someone had to pick that bill up, and according to the Council, it should be the school. Anyone in education will know that that level of debt is crippling for a school. And even though we managed to negotiate a payment holiday of a couple of years, the shadow of it hangs over Harrop, threatening to derail the progress we have made over the years. Independent school finance experts who were brought in to look at the debt and advise on ways to repay it recommended to the Council that they should write it off. This fell on deaf ears. Taking part in the first series of Educating Greater Manchester was all about singing from the rooftops about how amazing our students and staff are, and about raising the profile of the school. As a result, I have been fortunate enough to get involved in leadership development work in the corporate sector, and also wrote a leadership book called Educating Drew. The proceeds from both the leadership work and book have all gone towards paying off the debt – around pound, in total.  But it seems that the combination of me refusing to keep my mouth shut about the debt, together with the prospect of another series of Educating Greater Manchester was the straw that broke the camel’s back, and the Council had decided enough was enough. I must go. The ensuing investigation has been harrowing. It has been dficult both professionally and personally. It’s clear to me that Council have attempted to bully me, but I am not someone to take that sort of thing lying down. And so I decided that I needed to take a stand. It was put to me that I could go quietly, and accept a pay deal and go on gardening leave – which would, of course, involve a gagging clause. But it’s just not in my nature to do that. Since being suspended in July, I have been astounded and appalled by the number of other Heads and leaders that have come forward to say that they have suffered similar treatment, but they felt they had no option other than to go quietly. The stories have been distressing – families being torn apart, people on medication, educators – great educators – unable to work. This cannot be allowed to go on. I have made clear to Salford City Council that I will continue to co-operate with any investigation. I continue to publicly acknowledge that mistakes were made, and that as the leader of Harrop, I take responsibility for those mistakes. Just last week though, Harrop has been dealt yet another blow, with an Ofsted report that points to many problems in the school. I readily acknowledge that Harrop is a challenging school and that mistakes certainly happened on my watch, but the school I left in July bears no resemblance to the school described in Ofsted report. To me, this just illustrates all the more, thatyou destabilise a vulnerable school, things can go wrong at a quite shocking speed. I have no doubt that all sorts of accusations will be thrown around in the days and months to come, and this whole experience has been an education in itself on human behaviour – both good and bad.   Tens of thousands of hours of footage have been taken at Harrop Fold over the last few years – all from   fixed point cameras. I’m not going to comment on the fairness of an inspection regime that doesn’t allow those being criticised the right to reply, so I say only this:surelythis catalogue of issues are all “historic” as is being claimed, this would have been evident in both the first series of Educating Greater Manchester, and indeed in the one to come. I’m a die-hard optimist by nature so I do believe that the truth will out, one way or another. I have been humbled by the support I have been given on social media and in person, and I have been shocked at the depths some people will sink to. But in all of this, amidst all the accusations and recriminations, only one thing matters, and that is the kids of Harrop. They are the stars, and they will continue to shine no matter work.

story: NewsopinionA cosmetic nip and tuck takes away another mum’s leTryce Harry wanted to look more curvy, younger, perhaps like she’d done a few years back. And that terrible quest to look a little dferent has ended in her deathShareCommentsByAlison PhillipsDaily Mirror Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionLouise Harvey, , who died after developing a blood clot following a boob job "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTryce Harry was a loving we and mother. According to her devastated husband Kirk she “wanted to live more than anything ”. But as our story in this paper tells today – she also wanted to look a little dferent more curvy, younger, perhaps like she’d done a few years back. And that terrible quest to look a little dferent has ended in her death from a cardiac arrest following a bottom op or ‘bum lt’ at a clinic in Hungary. She’d initially only wanted a tummy tuck, breast lt and liposuction. But the offer of a freebie bum lt was presumably too good to resist.  There are few of us in our late s who’ve been through the ravages of childbirth and all that follows who don’t wish we were a little more taut or toned. . And while cosmetic surgery was for a long time regarded as an shyindulgence for the young, vain or feckless – it’s now within the budgets and imaginations of us all. Which is why the realities of its dangers need to be in the minds of us all too – and why today’s warning by Kirk so needs to be heard. For Tryce’s terrible story is by no means unique. Only last week we told the story of how another mum – -year-old Louise Harvey – died after developing a blood clot following a boob job.  And in August, Leah Cambridge, another young mum of three, died after undergoing a bum lt in Turkey. These, tragically, are just the tip of the iceberg. More than , British women every year are suffering complications as they jump on cheap flights to even cheaper foreign clinics in the hope of finding the perfect body. The number of Brits travelling abroad for elective surgery is thought to be up by between % and %. On days when we  and -something women feel fat and frumpy and invisible to the outside world, it is easy to be lured by the idea youth can be regained for less than the price of a family holiday. It’s an opportunity which can sound too good to be true. Tryce’s tragic tale reminds us once more that anything that sounds too good to be true... probably is.

title: labour mps vote against tory
story: NewsopinionLabour MPs will vote against Tory Brexit - we have to end the need for foodbanksUntil there is a solution to Britains poverty, no one should trust them, says AIison McGovernShareCommentsByAlison McGovern:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionAlison McGovern has explained what she thinks our best options are "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the crucial Brexit vote approaches and Britains future hangs in the balance, Labour MP for Wirral South AIison McGovern explains what she thinks our best options are. This Tory Government is a shambles. I am reminded of this every time I walk into the House of Commons and look at the Tory frontbench. Do they see the country as we do  Do they care that young families are living off foodbanks  How do they explain to their kids why more and more people are sleeping on our streets  Can we trust the Tories with the future of our country  Since  the answer has been no. And that’s why Labour MPs will vote against this Tory Brexit next week. We have to end the need for foodbanks.  We have to get people off the streets. This should be the priority for towns all over Britain. Until there is a solution to that, no one should trust the Tories on our future. Worse than that though, May’s Brexit deal isn’t even a plan. Brexit has already taken up two long years in which the Prime Minister couldn’t even get the Tories in her own Cabinet to agree, let alone her MPs. The House of Commons is in deadlock. That’s why all she is offering now is a vague ‘political statement’, which tells us nothing about the future. If we vote for it, we will be voting for two more years of wrangling and greater uncertainty. It will drag on and on and on. Many Labour members and voters are coming to the conclusion that the only way out of this mess is to let the public have the final say.  Parliament has ground to a halt. Meanwhile poverty is rising. If we can’t boot the Tories out with a general election then let’s take power form their hands and give the final verdict to the public. Has Brexit been a resounding success  Do we trust the Tories with our country  I think we all know the answer to that.
